sen.j: 天平文化（てんぴょうぶんか）は、時期では7世紀終わり頃から8世紀の中頃までをいい、奈良の都平城京を中心にして華開いた貴族・仏教文化である。
sen.e: Tenpyo Bunka (Tenpyo Culture) was an aristocratic and Buddhist culture florished in and around Heijo-kyo, the ancient capital city of Japan in current Nara, in the period from the end of the 7th century through the middle of the 8th century.

Tenpyo Culture was an aristocratic and Buddhist culture that flourished in and around Heijo-kyo, the ancient capital of Japan in current Nara, from the end of the 7th century through the middle of the 8th century.

Tenpyo Culture was an aristocratic and Buddhist culture that flourished in and around Heijo-kyo, the ancient capital of Japan in current Nara, from the end of the seventh century through the middle of the eighth century.

sen.j: この文化を、聖武天皇のときの元号天平を取って天平文化と呼ぶ。
sen.e: This culture is named Tenpyo Culture after the name of era "Tenpyo" under the reign of Emperor Shomu.
The name comes from the Tenpyo era of Emperor Shomu's reign.
The name comes from the Tenpyo era of Emperor Shomu's reign.

sen.j: 律令制が確立して中央集権的な国家体制が整うにつれて、国の富は中央に集められ、皇族や貴族はこれらの富を背景に華やかな生活を送った。
sen.e: Following the realization of Ritsuryo system and establishment of centralized state government, treasures and wealth of the country were gathered up in its capital city, in which cercumstances Imperial families and nobles enjoyed their gorgeous lives.

Following the realization of the Ritsuryo legal code and establishment of a centralized state government, the country's treasures and wealth were brought to the capital, against which background the Imperial family and the nobility led a sumptuous life.

Following the realization of the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) and establishment of a centralized state government, the country's treasures and wealth were brought to the capital, against which background the Imperial family and the nobility led a sumptuous life.
sen.cmt: 「律令制」を定訳に変更。「which background」はＮＣが書かれているので正しい表現だと思いますが、一応、ご確認願います。

sen.j: 当時の貴族は遣唐使などによってもたらされた唐の進んだ文化を持つことに大きな熱意を持っていた。
sen.e: The nobility in that era had a great zeal for advanced cultures brought from Tang by Kentoshi (Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty of China).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The nobility of the time had a great appetite for the advanced culture of Tang Dynasty China, brought back by Japanese envoys.
The nobility of the time had a great appetite for the advanced culture of Tang Dynasty China, brought back by Japanese envoys.

sen.j: そのため、天平文化も周（武周）の武則天や唐の玄宗 の文化の影響を強く受けた文化であった。
sen.e: Accordingly Tenpyo Culture was much influenced by Chinese cultures of Busokuten of Bushu Dynasty and Genso (Tang) of Tang Dynasty.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Accordingly, Tenpyo Culture was much influenced by the cultures of Empress Wu Zetian of the Zhou Dynasty and Emperor Xuanzong of Tang.
Accordingly, Tenpyo Culture was much influenced by the cultures of Empress Wu Zetian of the Zhou Dynasty and Emperor Xuanzong of Tang.
sen.cmt: (唐) をウェブで確認し、原文から削除しました。訳文は正しいです。

sen.j: このような唐からの文化移入には特に太宰府の果たした役割が大きいと考えられる。
sen.e: With such cultural transfer from Tang, China, to Japan, Dazaifu, a local government office in Kyushu, is considered to have played a big role.
Dazaifu, the government's headquarters in Kyushu, is considered to have played a major role in this transfer of culture from Tang.
Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region) is considered to have played a major role in this transfer of culture from Tang.

sen.j: 一方、国衙（こくが）・国分寺などに任命された国司（貴族）・官人や僧侶などによって地方にも新しい文物がもたらされた。
sen.e: On the other hand, various products of the new culture were also distributed to local regions by provincial governors (nobles), government officials and monks, who were delegated to kokuga (provincial government offices) and Kokubun-ji Temles (provincial monastries).

At the same time, various products of the new culture were also distributed to local regions by provincial governors (nobles), government officials and monks, who were delegated to kokuga (provincial government offices) and kokubun-ji (provincial temples).

At the same time, various products of the new culture were also distributed to local regions by provincial governors (nobles), government officials and monks, who were delegated to kokuga (provincial government offices) and kokubun-ji (provincial temples).

sen.j: このようにして、中国風（漢風）・仏教風の文化の影響が日本列島の地域社会へ浸透していった。
sen.e: In this way, influence of the Chinese and Buddhist style cultures penetrated into local societies of the Japanese archipelago.
In this way, the influence of the Chinese and Buddhist style cultures began to permeate down to regional communities throughout the Japanese archipelago.
In this way, the influence of the Chinese and Buddhist style cultures began to permeate down to regional communities throughout the Japanese archipelago.

sen.j: シルクロードによって西アジアから唐へもたらされたものが、遣唐使を通じて日本にやってきたりした。
sen.e: Some cultures were brought from West Asia via Tang, which had once been transferred from West Asia to Tang and then to Japan by Kento-shi (Japanese envoys to Tang).
Some cultures were brought from West Asia along the Silk Road to Tang, and then to Japan by Japanese envoys.
Some cultures were brought from West Asia along the Silk Road to Tang, and then to Japan by Japanese envoys.

sen.j: 平城京碁盤の目のような条坊制が布かれた。
sen.e: Heijo-kyo (an ancient capital city of Japan) had its streets and avenues, each of them being crossed at right angle under the jobo-sei system (a street plan of ancient capital).
Heijo-kyo was laid out in a grid pattern based on what was called the jobo system.
Heijo-kyo was laid out in a grid pattern based on what was called the jobo system.

sen.j: そこには多くの官衙（役所）が立てられ、貴族や庶民の家が瓦で葺き、柱には丹（に）を塗ることが奨励された。
sen.e: In Heijo-kyo city, a lot of kanga (government offices) were built, and houses of nobles and ccmmon people were recommended to have tiled-roofing and vermilion-colored pillars.
A lot of government offices were built, and nobles and common people were encouraged to build houses with tiled roofs and vermilion-colored pillars.
A lot of government offices were built, and nobles and common people were encouraged to build houses with tiled roofs and vermilion-colored pillars.

sen.j: また、飛鳥に建てられた大寺院が次々と移転された。
sen.e: Also, large temples once built in Asuka were relocated in succession into Heijo-kyo.
Also, large temples that had stood in Asuka were relocated one by one in Heijo-kyo.
Also, large temples that had stood in Asuka were relocated one by one in Heijo-kyo.

sen.j: このようにして「咲く花のにおうが如く今盛りなり」と歌われた平城京が出来上がった。
sen.e: Thus, Heijo-kyo became such a florishing place as people assimilated it in poems to "scentful flowers in bloom."
As a result, the completed Heijo-kyo was compared in poems to "fragrant flowers in bloom."
As a result, the completed Heijo-kyo was compared in poems to 'flourishing like fragrant flowers in bloom.'
sen.cmt: 「如く今盛りなり」の部分として、flourishing like を加えました。" "→' '

sen.j: 聖武天皇により諸国に僧寺（国分寺）・尼寺（国分尼寺）を建て、それぞれに七重の塔を作り、金光明最勝王経と妙法蓮華経を一部ずつ置くことにした。
sen.e: Emperor Shomu decided to construct provincial monastries (Kokubun-ji temples) and provincial nunneries (Kokubun-niji temples) in all provinces, each of which had a seven-story pagoda and kept each one sutra of Konkomyo-saishoo-kyo Sutra (Golden Light of the Most Victorious Kings Sutra) and Myohorenge-kyo Sutra (Lotus Sutra).

Emperor Shomu decided to construct provincial monasteries (kokubun-ji) and provincial nunneries (kokubun-niji) in all provinces, each of which had a seven-story pagoda and one copy each of the Golden Light Sutra and the Lotus Sutra.

Emperor Shomu decided to construct provincial monasteries (kokubun-ji) and provincial nunneries (kokubun-niji) in all provinces, each of which had a seven-story pagoda and one copy each of the Golden Light Sutra and the Lotus Sutra.

sen.j: その総本山と位置づけられる総国分寺・総国分尼寺が東大寺、法華寺である。
sen.e: As their grand head temples, the Principal Kokubun-ji Temple and the Principal Kokubun-niji Temple were Todai-ji Temple and Hokke-ji Temple, respectively.
sen.cmt: 用語の共有では「総国分寺」は"so-kokubun-ji Temple (principal protector temple of the land)"とされ、「総国分尼寺」は"Sokokubun-ni-ji Temple (the general nunnery temple)"とされています。 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The head temple of all the kokubun-ji was Todai-ji Temple and that of the kokubun-niji was Hokke-ji Temple.
The head temple of all the kokubun-ji was Todai-ji Temple and that of the kokubun-niji was Hokke-ji Temple.

sen.j: 東大寺盧舎那仏像は、鎮護国家の象徴として建立された。
sen.e: The statue of Birushana Buddha at Todai-ji Temple was constructed as a symbol of Chingo-kokka (keeping the nation tranquil).
The statue of Birushana Buddha at Todai-ji Temple was constructed as a symbol of national pacification (chingo kokka).
The statue of Birushana Buddha at Todai-ji Temple was constructed as a symbol of national pacification (chingo kokka).

sen.j: この大事業を推進するには幅広い民衆の支持が必要であったため、行基を大僧正として迎え、協力を得た。
sen.e: Since a wide support of common people was required to promote this big project to build the statue of Birushana Buddha, a popular monk Gyoki was welcomed as Daisojo (a Buddhist priest of the highest order) for his cooperation.
In order to garner the broad public support needed to promote this huge project, the government recruited the priest Gyoki, who was given the rank of Daisojo (the highest priestly rank).
In order to garner the broad public support needed to promote this huge project, the government recruited the priest Gyoki, who was given the rank of Daisojo (the highest priestly rank).

sen.j: 代表的な仏教建築
sen.e: Leading Architecture:
Major Buddhist Architecture
Major Buddhist Architecture

sen.j: 唐招提寺金堂・講堂
sen.e: The main hall and the lecture hall of Toshodai-ji Temple:
The main hall and lecture hall of Toshodai-ji Temple
The main hall and lecture hall of Toshodai-ji Temple

sen.j: - 講堂は、平城宮の東朝集殿を移築改造したもの。
sen.e: The lecture hall was built by transferring and remodeling "Higashi Choshu-den"(a government building) of Heijo-kyu Palace.
- The lecture hall was built by moving and remodeling Heijo-kyu Palace's "Higashi-choshuden"(Eastern Morning Audience Hall).
- The lecture hall was built by moving and remodeling Heijo-kyu Palace's "Higashi-choshuden"(Eastern Morning Audience Hall).
sen.cmt: 「東朝集殿」の説明をＮＣが変更されて用語集とは異なりますが、ＯＫと考えます。

sen.j: 薬師寺東塔
sen.e: East Pagoda of Yakushi-ji Temple:
Yakushi-ji Temple's East Pagoda
Yakushi-ji Temple's East Pagoda

sen.j: 東大寺法華堂（三月堂）、転害門
sen.e: Hokke-do Hall (also called "Sangastu-do Hall") of Todai-ji Temple, and Tengai-mon Gate:
sen.cmt: 共有単語では「転害門」は"Tengaimon (literally, "the gate of shifting the evil")"と訳されています。
sen.e: Todai-ji Temple's Hokke-do Hall (also called "Sangastu-do Hall") and Tengai-mon Gate
Todai-ji Temple's Hokke-do Hall (also called "Sangastu-do Hall") and Tengai-mon Gate

sen.j: 正倉院宝庫（校倉造）
sen.e: Shoso-in Treasure House (of Azekura-zukuri style of architecture):
Shoso-in Treasure House (Azekura-zukuri style of architecture)
Shoso-in Treasure Repository (Azekura-zukuri style of architecture)
sen.cmt: 正倉院は用語集で登録の多い表記に変更しました。

sen.j: 法隆寺東院夢殿
sen.e: Yumedono in Toin of Horyu-ji Temple (Hall of Dreams in East Precinct of Horyu-ji Temple):
Yumedono (Hall of Dreams) in Horyu-ji Temple's Toin (Eastern Precinct)
Yumedono (Hall of Dreams) in Horyu-ji Temple's Toin (Eastern Precinct)

sen.j: 万葉集
sen.e: Manyoshu (the oldest anthology of tanka or 31syllables' poems):
Manyoshu (the oldest anthology of tanka or 31-syllable poems)
Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves)

sen.j: 代表的な歌人：大伴旅人・大伴家持・山上憶良『貧窮問答歌』・山部赤人
sen.e: Leading Poets: OTOMO no Tabito, OTOMO no Yakamochi, YAMANOUE no Okura (famous for his poems "Bingu-mondoka"), and YAMABE no Akahito:
Main poets: OTOMO no Tabito, OTOMO no Yakamochi, YAMANOUE no Okura (famous for his poems "Bingu-mondoka"), and YAMABE no Akahito
Main poets: OTOMO no Tabito, OTOMO no Yakamochi, YAMANOUE no Okura (famous for his poems "Bingu-mondoka"), and YAMABE no Akahito

sen.j: 懐風藻（かいふうそう）
sen.e: Kaifuso (Fond recollections of poetry)
Kaifuso (Fond Recollections of Poetry)
Kaifuso (Fond Recollections of Poetry)

sen.j: 淡海三船・石上宅嗣(異説あり)
sen.e: Compilers: OMI no Mifune and ISONOKAMI no Yakatsugu (though different opinions exist)
Compilers: OMI no Mifune and ISONOKAMI no Yakatsugu (though different opinions exist)
Compilers: OMI no Mifune and ISONOKAMI no Yakatsugu (though different opinions exist)

sen.j: 東大寺の造営を管轄する役所である造東大寺司のもとで官営の造仏所が整備され、多数の工人によって仏像製作が分業的に行われていた。
sen.e: Many craftsmen were engaged in production of Buddha statues, according to divisions of labors, at well arranged governmental workshops for statues of Buddha under the administration of the Office of Todai-ji Temple Construction that controlled the project of Todai-ji Temple.

Many craftsmen were engaged, almost like an assembly line, in the production of Buddha statues at government workshops under the administration of the Office of Todai-ji Temple Construction, which controlled the Todai-ji Temple project.

Many craftsmen were engaged, almost like an assembly line, in the production of Buddha statues at government workshops under the administration of the Office of Todai-ji Temple Construction, which controlled the Todai-ji Temple project.

sen.j: 一方、都には民間の仏像制作工房：私仏所があり、また僧侶で仏像制作を行う者もでてきた。
sen.e: On the otherhand, there existed private workshops for Buddha statues in the capital city, as well as some monks started production of Buddhist images.
However, there also existed private workshops of Buddhist sculptors in the capital, as well as monks who produced Buddhist images.
However, there also existed private workshops of Buddhist sculptors in the capital, as well as monks who produced Buddhist images.

sen.j: 指導的仏師としては、東大寺大仏の責任者：国中連麻呂、興福寺の十大弟子八部衆制作の将軍万福などが記録に残っている。
sen.e: Names of leading sculptors of Buddhist statues recorded in history include KUNINAKA no Murajimaro who was a responsible official for construction of Great Buddha at Todai-ji Temple, and Manpuku SHOGUN who produced Judaideshi and Hachibushu (Ten Great Disciples and Eight Guardian Devas) at Manpuku-ji Temple.

Names of leading sculptors of Buddhist statues recorded in history include KUNINAKA no Murajimaro, who was responsible for the construction of the Great Buddha at Todai-ji Temple, and Manpuku SHOGUN, who produced Judaideshi and Hachibushu (Ten Great Disciples and Eight Guardian Devas) at Manpuku-ji Temple.

Names of leading sculptors of Buddhist statues recorded in history include KUNINAKA no Murajimaro, who was responsible for the construction of the Great Buddha at Todai-ji Temple, and Manpuku SHOGUN, who produced Judaideshi and Hachibushu (Ten Great Disciples and Eight Guardian Devas) at Manpuku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 東大寺盧舎那仏像は、奈良の大仏とも呼ばれ、天平時代の部分は台座、脚部などごく一部であった。
sen.e: Todaiji Rushana Butsuzo (the statue of Birushana Buddha at Todai-ji Temple), also called "Nara no Daibutsu" ("Great Buddha in Nara") was not completely constructed but only its pedestal, legs and other parts were laid down during the Tenpyo Period.
Parts of Todai-ji Temple's statue of Birushana Buddha, also called "Nara no Daibutsu" ("Great Buddha of Nara"), cast during the Tenpyo Period include its pedestal and legs.
Parts of Todai-ji Temple's statue of Birushana Buddha, also called "Nara no Daibutsu" ("Great Buddha of Nara"), cast during the Tenpyo Period include its pedestal and legs.

sen.j: これに代表される金銅仏のほか、乾漆造や塑像が主流であり、金像銀像、石仏も制作され、専仏、押出仏の制作も盛んで、制作技法が多様であった。
sen.e: Beside such gilt bronze statues of Buddha as represented by the Great Buddha at Todai-ji Temple, there were various kinds of Buddhist images produced by different methods including the most popular kanshitsuzo (lacquered wooden Buddha statues) and sozo (earthen images) as well as golden or silvery images, stone statues and also molded or extruded clay forms.

Beside such gilt bronze statues as the Great Buddha at Todai-ji Temple, various methods of producing Buddhist images were used, including the most popular kanshitsuzo (dry lacquer wooden statues) and sozo (earthen images), as well as gold or silver images, stone statues and also molded or extruded clay forms.

Beside such gilt bronze statues as the Great Buddha at Todai-ji Temple, various methods of producing Buddhist images were used, including the most popular kanshitsuzo (dry lacquer wooden statues) and sozo (earthen images), as well as gold or silver images, stone statues and also molded or extruded clay forms.

sen.j: 乾漆像
sen.e: Kanshitsuzo (dry lacquered wooden Buddha statues):
Kanshitsuzo (dry lacquered wooden Buddha statues)
Kanshitsuzo (dry lacquered wooden Buddha statues)

sen.j: 興福寺八部衆立像（阿修羅像など）、十大弟子立像
sen.e: The standing statues of Hachibushu (eight guardian devas) including Asura (fighting demon), and the standing statues of Judaideshi (ten great disciples), both at Kofuku-ji Temple:
The standing statues of Hachibushu (Eight Guardian Devas), including Asura (fighting demon), and the standing statues of Judaideshi (Ten Great Disciples), both at Kofuku-ji Temple
The standing statues of Hachibushu, including Asura (fighting demon), and the standing statues of Judaideshi, both at Kofuku-ji Temple

sen.j: 聖林寺十一面観音立像
sen.e: The standing statue of eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy) at Shorin-ji Temple:
The standing statue of eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy) at Shorin-ji Temple
The standing statue of eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy) at Shorin-ji Temple

sen.j: 唐招提寺金堂盧舎那仏坐像、鑑真和上坐像
sen.e: The seated statues of Birushana Buddha and the priest Ganjin at the main hall of Toshodai-ji Temple:
The seated statues of Birushana Buddha and the priest Ganjin in the main hall of Toshodai-ji Temple
The seated statues of Birushana Buddha and the priest Ganjin in the main hall of Toshodai-ji Temple

sen.j: 東大寺法華堂（三月堂）不空羂索観音立像、梵天・帝釈天立像、四天王立像、金剛力士・密迹力士立像
sen.e: The standing statues of Fuku-kensaku-kannon, Bonten and Taishakuten, Shitenno, and Kongo-rikishi and Misshaku-rikishi, all at Hokke-do Hall (also called "Sangatsu-do Hall") of Todai-ji Temple:

The standing statues of Fukukensaku Kannon, Bonten (Brahma) and Taishakuten (Sakra), Shitenno (the Four Heavenly Kings), and Kongorikishi and Misshakurikishi (Guardians), all in Todai-ji Temple's Hokke-do Hall (also called "Sangatsu-do Hall")

The standing statues of Fukukensaku Kannon, Bonten (Brahma) and Taishakuten (Sakra), Shitenno (the Four Heavenly Kings), and Kongorikishi and Misshakurikishi (Guardians), all in Todai-ji Temple's Hokke-do Hall (also called "Sangatsu-do Hall")

sen.j: 塑像
sen.e: Sozo (earthen statues):
Sozo (earthen statues)
Sozo (earthen statues)

sen.j: 新薬師寺（奈良市）十二神将立像（うち1躯は昭和期の補作）
sen.e: The standing statues of Juni-shinsho (twelve Heavenly Generals) at Shin-Yakushi-ji Temple (Nara City), one of which statues was supplemented during the Showa Period:
The standing statues of Juni-shinsho (Twelve Heavenly Generals) at Shin-Yakushi-ji Temple (Nara City), one of which was altered during the Showa Period (1926-1989)
The standing statues of Juni-shinsho (Twelve Heavenly Generals) at Shin-Yakushi-ji Temple (Nara City), one of which was altered during the Showa Period (1926-1989)

sen.j: 東大寺法華堂執金剛神立像、日光菩薩・月光菩薩立像、弁才天・吉祥天立像
sen.e: The standing statues of Shitsu Kongoshin, Nikko and Gakko Bosatsu, Benzaiten and Kisshoten, all at Hokke-do Hall of Todai-ji Temple:
The standing statues of Shitsukongoshin (Vajrapani), Nikko and Gakko Bosatsu (Suryaprabha and Candraprabha Bodhisattvas), Benzaiten (Saraswati) and Kisshoten, all at Hokke-do Hall of Todai-ji Temple
The standing statues of Shitsukongoshin (Vajrapani), Nikko and Gakko Bosatsu (Suryaprabha and Candraprabha Bodhisattvas), Benzaiten (Saraswati) and Kisshoten, all at Hokke-do Hall of Todai-ji Temple

sen.j: 東大寺戒壇院四天王立像
sen.e: The standing statue of Shitenno at Kaidan-in Hall of Todai-ji Temple:
The standing statue of Shitenno in Todai-ji's Kaidan-in Hall
The standing statue of Shitenno in Todai-ji's Kaidan-in Hall

sen.j: 正倉院宝物（楽器、調度品など）
sen.e: Treasures at Shoso-in Hall of Todai-ji Temple (musical instruments, furnishing goods, etc.)
Treasures (musical instruments, furnishings, etc.) in Todai-ji's Shoso-in Hall
Treasures (musical instruments, furnishings, etc.) in Todai-ji's Shoso-in Treasure Repository
